In the past, there was a great king named AÅ›oka. He ruled over all countries without fail.
The great king was wise and had immeasurable wisdom.
He asked his ministers,
Are there any in the world who do not belong to me?
The ministers replied,
The whole world belongs to the great king.
There is none who does not submit.
Among them, a wise minister replied,
Within the king's realm, there are those who do not belong to the king.
In the ocean, there is a dragon king who does not belong to the great king.
He has never sent a message nor offered tribute.
Therefore, we know he does not belong to the great king.
The king may test him.
A thousand carriages and ten thousand cavalry,
beating drums and blowing conches,
with banners and flags guarding in front and back, arrived at the seashore.
The dragon king remained silent and did not come out.
The king then called out,
You are within my realm.
Why do you not come out?
He also remained silent and did not respond to the king.
The king then asked the wise minister,
How can we make the dragon king submit?
The wise minister replied,
We can make him submit.
The dragon king has great blessings and virtue.
Because of this, he is unwilling to submit.
If the great king does not believe the minister's words,
weigh two images cast from two pounds of gold,ğŸ”½one made in the king's likeness,
and one made in the dragon king's likeness.
Then weigh them again.ğŸ”½The dragon king's image will be heavier.
The great king's image will be lighter.
Therefore, we know the dragon king has many blessings and virtue.
The great king has few blessings and virtue.
The king's heart was greatly enlightened.
He was overjoyed beyond measure.
He announced to the world to serve and support the orphaned and elderly.
He provided for the poor and needy.
In every prefecture, they established shrines for the Heavenly Venerable.
And set up temples for the Heavenly Venerable to make offerings to the assembly.
After three years, they weighed the dragon image and the king's image again.
The dragon image became lighter.
The king's image became heavier.
The wise minister said to the king,
The dragon can be subdued.
He then set up a grand procession as before and went to the seashore again.
The dragon king transformed into a young brahmin.
He knelt before the king and asked about his well-being.
He offered precious treasures from the ocean.
He declared himself a vassal.
The people of the land were all delighted.
It is explained separately in the sutra text.
To show to the people of later generations.
There is no greater strength in the world than the blessings and virtues.
People protect the Dharma as a mother protects her child.
How could it not be worth thinking about?
In the past, when the Heavenly Venerable was in the world,
he took his disciples to teach and transform the masses. He saw a piece of paper on the ground.
His disciple Ananda immediately picked it up.
The Heavenly Venerable told Ananda to let it go.
Ananda immediately let it go.
His hand then became fragrant.
He walked a little further and saw a whirlwind blowing grass onto the ground.
Ananda picked it up again.
The Heavenly Venerable told Ananda to let it go.
His hand then became foul-smelling.
Ananda did not understand.
We will soon arrive at the monastery and can ask about this matter then.

and holding grass make one's hands smelly?
The World-Honored One said to Ä€nanda,ğŸ”½Paper originally comes from fragrant soil,
so it makes the paper fragrant.
Therefore, it makes your hands fragrant.
Grass comes from smelly soil,
so it makes your hands smelly.
Being close to the wise is like fragrance adhering to paper,
while being close to the wicked is like stench adhering to grass.
Therefore, the sutra says, Being close to the wise perfects wisdom,
while being close to the foolish increases delusion.ğŸ”½There are three ways to harm oneself,
and three ways to benefit oneself.
This is why one should be careful.
In the past, the World-Honored One went to the riverbank with his disciples.
The World-Honored One said to his disciples,
Take a fistful of stones,
and see if they float or sink in the water.
The disciples replied,
The stones sink to the bottom of the water.
The World-Honored One said,
Because they have no conditions.
Furthermore, there was a square stone measuring three feet.
Placing it on the water, he crossed the river and the stone did not get wet. How could this be so?
The disciples did not understand and all wondered about it.
The disciples knelt for a long time and said to the Buddha,
What is the reason for this?
The Heavenly Venerable said,
It is because of good conditions.
What are the conditions? The boat,
the Heavenly Venerable used it as a metaphor.
Those who meet a good teacher,
can escape from various sufferings.
Those who meet an evil teacher,
will learn evil things and not escape from various calamities.
It shows people of later generations,
they cannot be careless.
In the past, there was an extremely poor and lonely old man.
He had nothing to do for himself.
He encountered a market and got an axe.
This is the essence of all treasures.
But he did not recognize it.
He carried it to chop firewood and sell it,
to provide for his meager life. As the axe was about to be used up,
he saw a foreign merchant,
named Sabao.
Seeing the axe, he recognized it.
He then asked the old man,
Would you sell this axe?
The old man said,
I rely on this axe to chop firewood for a living, so I won't sell it.
The merchant said again,
If you give me a hundred bolts of silk, why wouldn't I sell it?
The old man thought he was being ridiculed,
and he also did not agree.
The merchant said again,
Why don't you agree?
If you give me two hundred bolts,
the old man then became sullen and unhappy.
The merchant said again,
If you dislike it being too little, I can add more.
Why are you unhappy?
If you give me five hundred bolts,
the old man then cried loudly, saying,
I don't resent the silk being too little.
I am foolish. This axe is one chi and five cun long. I have already used it to chop the ground to the end.
There are still five cun left, and I can still get five hundred bolts.
This is what I resent.
The merchant said again,
Don't continue to regret it.
Now I will give you a thousand bolts.
He then tore up the contract and took it away.
This axe is indeed the finest of all treasures.
Sabo did not ask how much it was worth and put the axe on top.
The firewood and fire burned it all, turning it into a precious treasure.
The Heavenly Venerable borrowed it as a metaphor.
Receiving a human body with the six faculties complete and sharp wisdom and eloquence,
One should rely on a wise teacher to seek the path to liberation from the world.
Spiritual powers can reach it.
But those who are attached to worldly affairs do not distinguish between true and false,
Like a plowman who releases the oxen when the world is at peace.
When he reaches old age and death, he will again suffer punishment.
It is like an old man using up his precious axe.
Isn't it a mistake?
In the past, there was a bird on the Long Range Mountains named a parrot.
It traveled far and ended up on Mount Tai in the east.
No bird or beast did not respect and love it.
Because it came from afar.
It became close friends and loved each other very much.ğŸ”½In the spring, when wild fires burned, it would enter the water.
Flying over the fire, it shook the water from its feathers.
Saving its friends from danger.
This happened more than once.
The crying and sighing were like the water of the parrot, which could not extinguish the fire.
The sincerity moved heaven, causing rain to fall.
The fire was immediately extinguished.
The Tianzun Sutra borrows this as a metaphor.
The wise one, with the Daoist coming from afar, studies the essence and practices the Dao.
Reducing one's own speech and body, encroaching on one's wife and children's share to make offerings to the Sangha.
Although there is no spiritual power to move,
It is also with utmost sincerity to burn incense and seek to extinguish.
Embracing the rituals, one attains immeasurable blessings.
It is like the rain from heaven, extinguishing all calamities.
In the past, there was a great elder whose wealth was immeasurable.
He stored a thousand bushels of grain in a pit, but later when he took it out, he could not find the grain.
He saw a small child, about three years old, who also did not know how to speak.
The elder also did not know the child's name or what it was.
He picked it up and went to the main road in front of the gate.
Even the passersby on the street recognized it.
To the east of the house, there came a cart.
The driver was a yellow ox, the person wore yellow clothes, and the followers were all yellow.
He saw a small child and said:
Why is the thief of grain sitting here?
This child is the spirit of the five grains.
Tell the elder to bring a shovel and axe.
I will tell you the location of a basin of gold.
The one who just passed by is the gold spirit.
Go west along the street and turn south at the intersection.
Walk two hundred steps.
To the west of the road, there will be an old decayed tree.
Under it, there is a ten-bushel jar of gold.
Go dig it up and use it to repay your grain debt.
The elder followed the child's instructions and obtained this, enough to manage his household and become greatly wealthy.
The Buddha's sutras are used as a metaphor.
Making offerings to the Sangha, widely setting up charitable gatherings, and spending a lot of money,
Is likened to losing grain.
Daoist masters lecturing on sutras, explaining the meaning, teaching people to stay away from evil and approach goodness,
Later obtaining immeasurable blessings, only then can they reach the Way.
Is likened to obtaining the jar of gold.
It is shown and told to people of later generations.
Meritorious virtue cannot not be created.
Regretting later is of no use.
In the past, there was a country that was prosperous, peaceful, and lacked nothing.
He then spoke to his ministers,
Send a capable minister to
another country to buy what we do not have.
He immediately sent a man to another country, who took precious treasures to buy things everywhere. Upon inspection, there were no other goods.
All of this is what we have in our country.
At the very end, he saw a wise man sitting in an empty shop.
He then asked him,
I do not see you selling anything.
Why are you sitting here empty-handed?
He replied, I am selling wisdom here.
He asked,
What does your wisdom look like and how much do you want to sell it for?
He replied,
My wisdom is worth five hundred taels of gold.
If you weigh that much gold, I will tell you.
The man from afar then thought to himself,
There is no place in our country that sells wisdom to people.
He then weighed five hundred taels of gold and gave it to the man.
He then told him the words of wisdom.
Twenty characters.
Long consider and contemplate carefully.
Do not act hastily in anger.
Even if not used today,
There will be a time when it is useful.
Thus, they received and recited it to become proficient, and each returned home.
The minister who obtained the words of wisdom immediately returned to his country and took a shortcut to his home.
At night, he entered the bed of his wife under the bright moon, and there were two shoes.
Suspecting there was a strange person, he gave rise to evil thoughts.
His wife suddenly fell ill, and her mother went to stay overnight.
She saw the elder still reciting the words of wisdom without stopping.
Her mother was startled and thought, Is my child coming back?
The child then ran out of the door and called out, Cheap! Cheap!
His mother asked him, Why are you calling out 'cheap'?
He said, My mother gave her daughter away for ten thousand taels of gold, but still did not give her to someone.
She is now looking for five hundred taels of gold. Isn't that cheap?
The Sutra of the Heavenly Honored One is borrowed as a metaphor.
A proverb says, One word of help is better than a thousand taels of gold.
This is what it means.
In the past, the Celestial Venerable was by the side of the Ganges River.
He extensively expounded the Dharma of the sutras.
At that time, heavenly dragons, ghosts, spirits, emperors, people, flying birds, and running beasts all came to listen to the Dharma.
At that time, there was an old cowherd who listened while leaning on his staff.
He did not realize that there was a toad under his staff.
The toad listened to the sutra with a beautiful intention.
He also did not realize that there was a staff on his back.
Eventually, the toad's life ended.
Its spirit was immediately reborn in the heavens.
Using the heavenly eye, he observed its origins.
From which path did it come? He saw its former body as a toad.
Heavenly flowers were scattered on its former body.
It showed and spoke to the people of later generations:
The toad listened to the sutra with a beautiful intention and was reborn in the heavens.
How much more so for the wise ones who listen to the sutra with utmost sincerity!
How could it not be lofty?
In the past, there were two brothers.
The younger brother followed a teacher of enlightenment and became a monk.
He eventually attained the path of an arhat.
He often came to speak to his older brother.
You should diligently create merit and virtue.
The elder brother said,
I am busy now, I will do it later.
This happened many times.
Later, the elder brother passed away.
The younger brother used his spiritual vision to observe where his elder brother's spirit had been reborn.
He looked in the heavens and the realm of humans, but did not see his spirit.
He then looked in the hells and the realm of hungry ghosts, but still did not see him.
He was then in the animal realm.
He saw his elder brother's spirit had become a large ox.
At that time, a merchant was driving the ox to make a living.
The ox was exhausted and fell into the mud, unable to get up.
The merchant beat it with a stick.
The ox still stretched its neck and did not get up.
The younger brother saw his elder brother like this.
He went straight to in front of the ox.
He said to his elder brother,
How busy are you today, compared to before?
The ox was ashamed and died.
The monk then left.
The merchants discussed among themselves,
Why did the monk come and curse our ox to death?
They then chased after the monk.
He took it back and asked about the appearance of the cow.
The practitioner told him the truth, saying, The cow is my elder brother.
He did not follow my words and thus incurred this punishment.
The practitioner then threw the bowl into the sky.
It flew after him.
The merchants knew he was a sage.
They then reproached themselves.
They burned incense and made merit for the cow.
Because of this merit, they were reborn in the heavens.
In the past, there was a wise person.
He lived thirty li southeast of the country of Shravasti.
His family door followed the Dharma and made offerings to practitioners.
The old man liked to kill pigs and sell meat.
The practitioners gradually became aware of this.
They had not yet reprimanded him.
The old man then passed away.
He received the form of a ghost in the Ganges River.
There were iron wheels with sharp edges like frost and snow.
They followed the current and stabbed him.
The pain was indescribable.ğŸ”½One day later, the practitioner crossed the Ganges River and encountered the ghost spirit.
The ghost then emerged halfway out of the water.
and said to the boatman:
Grab the monk and put him in the water.
If not, I will kill everyone on the boat.
At that time, a wise person asked the ghost:
Why do you want this monk?
The ghost said:
When I was in the world, I made offerings to monks.
The monks knew I was killing pigs and selling meat,
but they did not admonish me.
Therefore, I am killing monks.
The wise person said:
You are sitting here killing pigs, and you have already committed this sin.
Now you want to kill monks again.
Isn't your sin even greater?
The ghost thought to himself, It is really as the wise person says.
He then let them go.
The monk returned and told his family descendants:
Make offerings for him.
The spirit was then able to escape suffering.
He told people of later generations:
When monks receive offerings, they should not fail to admonish.ğŸ”½In the past, there was a person walking on the road.
He saw a dead person on the road.
The ghosts and spirits whipped him with sticks.
The traveler asked,
This person is already dead, why are you whipping him?
The ghosts and spirits said,
This is my former body.
In my previous life, I was unfilial to my parents.
I served my ruler without loyalty.
I did not respect the Three Jewels.
I did not follow the teachings of my teachers and elders.
It caused me to fall into suffering and pain, difficult to speak of.
It is my former body that came to whip me.
Gradually moving forward, he saw another dead person.
A celestial spirit came down and scattered flowers on the corpse of the dead person.
He rubbed it with his hands.
The traveler asked,
Judging from you, it seems you are a celestial being.
Why are you rubbing this corpse?
He replied,
This is my former body. In my previous life, I was filial to my parents.
I served my ruler with loyalty and trustworthiness.
I respectfully honored the Three Jewels.
I accepted the teachings of my teachers and elders.
It caused my spirit to be reborn in the heavens.
It is all due to the kindness of my former body.
Therefore, I have come to repay it.
The practitioner sees these two changes in one day.
Then he returns home, upholds the five precepts, and practices the ten wholesome deeds.
He is filial to his parents and loyal in serving the ruler.
He tells people of the future generations.
Karmic retribution of sins and merits pursues people for a long time and does not let them go.
One cannot be careless.

He studied the Way in the mountains.

In the market, there was a wise person sitting in a shop.
He saw the novice monk reciting while walking.
He asked the novice monk,
Why are you reciting while walking?
The novice monk replied,
My teacher is studying the Way in the mountains.
He holds me accountable for one dou of rice and one verse every day.
Therefore, I am reciting a verse while walking.
The wise person asked again,
If you don't pay the rice, how many verses can you memorize a day?
He said he could memorize ten verses.
The wise person then said,
Don't walk while reciting anymore.
I will myself supply the rice for the novice.
The novice was delighted and was able to sit in quietude and study.
The wise one provided nine bushels of rice for the novice.
Then he tested the novice's sutras, which he all understood.
The wise one was later born in the world as a disciple of the Heavenly Venerable.

The Heavenly Venerable had twelve divisions of scriptures.
The reward of being intelligent is that one knows ten things when asked one.
It is shown to people of later generations.
Merit and virtue follow the body like a shadow follows a form.
According to what one plants, one reaps its blessings.
It cannot not be done.
In the past, there was a butcher who raised a thousand head of cattle to be fattened.
He killed one cow a day and sold the meat.
After killing five hundred cows,
there were still five hundred head left.
They were jumping and frolicking together, bumping into each other.
The Heavenly Venerable entered the country at that time.
Seeing the cows like this, he felt pity and left.
He told his disciples,
These cows are foolish.
Only when their companions are about to leave do they play and make merry together.
People are also like this.
One day has passed.
People's lives are constantly decreasing. One should contemplate and diligently seek the path to liberation from the world.
